The Myth of the "Digital Native"
entry.content:
There is a theory going around, that anyone born in the last 20 or so years, is a "digital native" - understands technology, and is at home with it; can manipulate technology at will.

I do not think that this is correct.

Here is a video which has been posted on the TES's Youtube channel, which covers similar ground.


The main points that are drawn out are :

a

b

c

It seems to me that it is very easy to conclude that "the youth" are "digital natives" and that they will understand "computers" and all that that entails.  I do not think that this is correct.

I think that it is one thing to be able to make use of an pre-written application (be that Facebook, Twitter, TikTok, or Office 365) generally written with ease of use in mind; I think it is something else entirely to understand the process of the computation which goes on, and how that works.

I have a 9 year old daughter, who is very good at getting a computer to do what she wants, but ...

She knows nothing of algorithms; nothing of programming (in any real sense); nothing of data and how that works.  She can make the pre-written software do what she wants it to do, but is that being a digital native.

Perhaps an analogy here would be useful.  The closest that I can think of is the car analogy.  Just because you are a good driver, does not mean that you are a good mechanic, or engineer.  Being a good driver is important, useful, and probably a necessity in 2020; but it is different to being able to design and build a car; or to being able to maintain or modify a car once it has been built.

I think that these differences are important to recognise.  Otherwise, a certain generation will run away with the idea that simply because you are able to 'drive' the software, you are somehow able to build and manipulate the software.

Therefore, my focus with my children is less on being able to drive pre-written software, and more on getting my children to have a solid foundation in mathematics and physics, and then a good grounding in what software is, and what it is able to do.  That way, my children will be much better placed to make best use of technology, and perhaps develop into digital natives.

entry.title: Risks around Covid19
entry.content:
This morning I was listening to a podcast, which had originally been broadcast a few weeks ago - let’s say August, 2020. The subject was around understanding the risk for individuals posed by Covid19.

Amongst the plethora of statistics spouted, a couple stuck in my mind.

  1. the risk of an averagely healthy 65 year-old man, who has already caught Covid, of dying is 1%. So, this 65 year-old has caught the virus, and now wants to know how likely it is that he will die. Of 100 similar people (same age, same gender, same average health), 1 of these people will die. Out of 1000, 10 will die.
    The podcast did not cover, but I would be fascinated to know what the same numbers are for cancer? Or for (normal) influenza ?
  2. the second statistic was for an averagely healthy 75 year old man, and the number multiplied by 3 - so the percentage, given that you have already contracted Covid, is 3% that you will die. 3 people (averagely healthy men, of 75 years) out of 100 who have caught Covid will die; 30 out of 1000.
    Again the podcast was silent on similar stats for cancer, (normal) influenza, or car accidents.

Given these numbers, and these percentages, I am still very unclear as to how much effort, energy, and expense ought to be being put into avoiding catching the virus in the first place.

I will admit, and put my hands up, that I am a sceptic when it comes to using a lockdown to tackle this pandemic. The economics are disproportionate. You may feel that this is a matter beyond cost; that we should spend whatever money we can on saving a life. I do not think that this is correct.

It seems to me that the best thing that we could all do - government included - is to encourage being ‘normally’ healthy. Improve diet - improve exercise - cut down on sugars - cut down on alcohol - cut down on smoking. It seems to me that this is where government effort and energy ought to be expended. One of the side effects of that is that we as a nation would not be paying / have to be paying this massive economic price for the restrictions.

entry.title: The relentless - and welcome - approach of autumn
entry.content:
It’s just heading into Autumn. I love Autumn, and I love this time of year. The summer is now well and truly behind us. We are approaching the season of mists and mellow fruitfulness.

The colours turn to an autumn palette.

The temperatures drop … but not so much that it is uncomfortable, just enough to remind us that cold can be good.

When I go for a walk in the country, I hear the lonely, piercing shriek of the kite - hauntingly beautiful.

Chestnuts and conkers abound.

Bonfires approach.

Drifts of dry autumn leaves get closer.

link.title: The relentless - and welcome - approach of autumn

entry.title: Google Play Music - Youtube Music - Google Assistant - subscription model for music
entry.content:
Google Play Music is transitioning to Youtube Music - this has been going on for some time now; Google wants to stop the Google Play Music service. I am happy with this; I have no problem with this.

Fairly recently, Google has - at last ! - enabled uploading of your own music to the Youtube Music service. Previously, the lack of this upload of your own music has stopped me adopting the Youtube Music service.

All sounds good, so far ! And yet there is a problem ...

In my car, I make use of Android Auto - lots ! I love it. My in-car entertainment system does NOT have Android Auto built in - instead I make use of the Android Android Auto app running on my phone, which in turn connects with my in-car entertainment system via Bluetooth. Using the Android Auto app like this means that I can make use of Google Assistant whilst I am driving. I can say “Hey Google - navigate to work”, and off it goes. I can say “Hey Google - play some music” and hey presto - Android Auto (running Google Assistant) communicates with Google Play Music and tells it to play a random selection of music - the “I’m Feeling Lucky” mix, which is fantastic. But this leads me on to the problem. Google Assistant requires you to have a default music provider. I have mine set to Google Play Music, and this allows me the functionality that I am talking about. If I set the default music provider to Youtube Music, then when I ask it to play some music, it tells me that I need to have a subscription to Youtube Music for this to work. Which I do not want ! I just want it to play the music that I have already bought, ripped, and uploaded to (both) Google Play Music and Youtube Music.

In reality this is not an issue with Android Auto, but with Google Assistant and with Youtube Music, but until it gets sorted out, I will be sticking with Google Play Music as my default music provider on Google Assistant, so that I can get access to all the great functionality.

Once this is sorted out, I will very happily switch to Youtube Music.

The painful scenario would be where Google disable/switch off Google Play Music before sorting out the problem with being able to use Youtube Music without needing a subscription.

link.title: Google Play Music - Youtube Music - Google Assistant - subscription model for music

entry.title: A YouTube video that I encourage you to watch
entry.content:
I have been watching the YouTube channel, "Not Just Bikes", for some time now.

The channel is driven by a man who was born and grew up in Canada, and who's profession seems to be urban planning - at least that is his passion.

He has lived in a variety of places around the world, but has chosen, specifically, to live in the Netherlands, and Amsterdam specifically, largely based on aspects of urban planning, and the environment that thsi creates.

It is a really good channel, and I recommend it to you - his content is really good.

But I saw his most recent video (as at Spetember, 2020), and it struck such a chord with me, that I decided to write about it, and to encourage you to watch it.

Watching it brings to mind all sorts of thoughts and feelings for me - reminiscences about my own childhood; thoughts on how I am raising my own two children - all sorts.

I urge you to watch it, and to give some thought to teh environments that we have created for our children to grow up in, and how we contribute to this as well.

link.title: A YouTube video that I encourage you to watch

entry.title: The economic cost of commuting ... or of NOT commuting !
entry.content:
I am based in the UK. It is currently September, 2020. We are in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic, and the various efforts and attempts by governments all over the world to try to stem the tide.

In the UK - in my part of the UK - children have just started back to school after an amazingly long interruption. This has meant that parents are once again able to concentrate on work rather than having the overwhelming effort of childcare to consider.

The UK government is encouraging us all to get back to work - not just to work, but to get back to the office, with the commuting that this involves.

Many of us have been working from home for months, so returning to a daily commute will be a change - a change back to what we were once used to, but a change nonetheless.

All of this has got me thinking about the economic cost of commuting; or more exactly what the act of commuting contributes to the economy, and therefore what reduction in commuting costs the economy.

This post is not about the physical or emotional effect of commuting on individual commuters.

This post is also NOT about the cost savings that companies could potentially make, by reducing office space, and allowing their employees to work from home.

I am also NOT looking at the general economic downturn, and people’s understandable reluctance to spend, in uncertain times.

I am simply looking at commuting, and what a reduction in commuting might mean to government tax revenues, and to the economy in general.

One of the most obvious costs to the economy is related to the spend on fuel. If you are working from home, you are not having to drive anywhere, which means that you are not using petrol or diesel. This means that the tax revenue from these items is much reduced. It also means that the profits from fuel retailers (BP, Shell, etc.) are reduced - with the associated tax revenues from those profits.

When people commute, there is a time cost - either spent in a train, or in a car, or similar. Often this time is spent reading a newspaper/a magazine/ eating a snack. If you are not spending this time commuting, then you are not doing those distraction type activities. Once again, the government loses out on all the tax revenues associated with those purchases, and the retailers lose out on the associated profits.

Even if you are substituting a cup of coffee at home, for your favourite cup of Costa or Starbucks, you are spending far less to make the equivalent coffee at home, than you would be by buying a coffee shop coffee.

So, any conclusions that we can draw from this ?

From a government perspective, the idea of everyone working from home, surely cannot be appealing. From many points of view, it is far preferable to have the population spending hours in cars or on trains commuting than it is having them staying at home, and not spending money on distractions.

link.title: The economic cost of commuting ... or of NOT commuting !

entry.title: [book review] "Wolf Hall" by Hilary Mantel
entry.content:
Details of the Book

Title Wolf Hall
Author Hilary Mantel
ISBN 978-0007230204
Publisher / Imprint Fourth Estate

SRM Reading

Took me well over a month to read - in part because of constant distractions … but not wholly so. Finished in August, 2020.

Headline / Takeaway

I enjoyed much of this book, and I am glad that I read it. I would recommend the book, but with several caveats (see below), and I would not say that this book is well suited to all comers.

Story Synopsis

Link to Wikipedia article on "Wolf Hall"

Criticism

Who am I to criticise ? And yet, I do ! See my review, below, for my critique, which does includes some criticism.

Review

Hilary Mantel’s “Wolf Hall” is a long book - a meaty read. It is a book about which a lot of people have written, and those people have written lots about it. I am unlikely to add much of any substance, so all I can write about is my reaction to the book.

I was given the book for my birthday, by my family, so I wanted to read it, in part, out of a sense of obligation. Had I not had that, I’m not sure that I would have persevered.

I have read, and thoroughly enjoyed, all of the CJ Sansom “Shardlake” series, which cover certain amounts of the same time period, and some of the same characters. I find the Sansom books easy to follow and to comprehend, so I believe that I brought to the reading of the Mantel book knowledge which helped me immensely in understanding and following Mantel’s writing. Once again, without this prior knowledge, I am not sure how I would have fared.

The time period covered by Wolf Hall encompasses a fascinating period of English history, and also contains some truly fascinating characters.

I find certain characters to be fascinating - characters where the start was to some degree humble; the early rise down to their own efforts. I am sure that I am not alone in finding these sorts of characters fascinating, and presumably this is why books are written about such people. I think that Thomas Cromwell sits firmly in this category, and I also put Cicero in this group.

So, there is a great deal to like about the book and the subject matter. But … there is also some to take issue with.

I have seen criticism of the book about the density of the writing / the obscurity of the writing. Mantel has a tendency to write long tracts referring to “he” (which I think she sees clearly as being Thomas Cromwell), but in passages where there are multiple “he’s” involved - often including King Henry. It is often easy to be confused about whom Mantel refers to when she writes “he”.

Additionally, events do not seem to me, to be written clearly about. I think that this is Mantel using a writerly device to allow readers to understand that in the midst of great events, the protagonists often do not have great clarity. So when writers write about past events, with great clarity, this is disingenuous to say the least. A common criticism of literary history is that the writer writes the story, as though it were a set of steps which were almost pre-ordained. I think that Hilary Mantel is trying hard to avoid this, and to show that real-politics evolves rather than being part of a grand design.

A solid, and understandable writerly device. But one which adds to the sense of confusion and murkiness that one gets when reading the book.

In short, I enjoyed much of the book, and I am glad that I read it. I would recommend the book, but with several caveats, and I would not say that this book is well suited to all comers.

entry.title: [book review] "The Cursed Child" by JK Rowling and others
entry.content:
Details of the Book

Title Harry Potter and the Cursed Child
Author J K Rowling and others
ISBN 978-1410496201
Publisher / Imprint Thorndike Press

SRM Reading

Took me a few days in August/September, 2020.

Headline / Takeaway

My headline is that, as an enthusiast for the Harry Potter novels, I found this to be diverting and enjoyable - though ultimately less satisfying than I might have hoped for.

If you have read and enjoyed the Harry Potter books, then this is an entertaining foray back into the world of Hogwarts, Dumbledore and Voldemort.

Story Synopsis

Link to Wikipedia article on "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child"

Criticism

See below for more general comments.

Review

Let me start by saying that I really enjoyed the Harry Potter series of books when I first read them many years ago, and I have continued to enjoy them when I have periodically re-read them over the years. I have also enjoyed watching my daughter work her way through them, and enjoy them also.

Having set that background, I can say that I did enjoy the Cursed Child story … but not without reservation.

Unrelated to the actual story, I found that reading a story, by working my way through a play script, was not the simplest or most enjoyable experience. But I recognise that this is a play script, and was intended to be used as such, and not as a novel.

I think that perhaps the single most appealing aspect of the Harry Potter series is that you feel very close to the main characters; you want them to succeed. Here I did not feel as close to Albus or Scorpius as I would have liked - I did not care greatly about them. I am sure that if I was seeing this in a theatre as a stage performance, then I would have felt more invested in the main characters.

For me, it had the feel of a follow on film, or similar, which capitalises on the success of the initial installment.

link.title: [book review] "The Cursed Child" by JK Rowling and others

entry.title: [book review] "Never Let Me Go" by Kazuo Ishiguro
entry.content:
Details of the Book

Title Never Let Me Go
Author Kazuo Ishiguro
ISBN 978-0571258093
Publisher / Imprint Faber and Faber

SRM Reading

I read this book many years ago, and even went so far as to write a review of it on Amazon. I came across the Amazon review again in August, 2020, and this post is that Amazon review, re-published here on my blog.

The title that I gave my Amazon review was “How to Farm a Human Being”.

Headline / Takeaway

An excellent book which I would highly recommend.

Story Synopsis

Link to Wikipedia article on "Never Let Me Go"

Criticism

I have no criticism to make of this novel.

Review

I think that the sub-title for this novel should be "How to Farm a Human Being".

The headline for my reaction to, and thoughts about this novel, is that this is another truly good novel from this excellent author - I really enjoyed reading this.

Now comes the analysis, which is much more difficult. I am not going to try to precis the story - that is done much more effectively elsewhere. All that I will try to do here is to outline some of the topics that the novel raised for me, and what I felt about them.

I would describe this as a "sociological" science fiction novel - not a genre which I think is over crowded.

The premise of the novel is not very far fetched, I think.

It seems to me that Ishiguro is fascinated by the ordinariness of dystopia, and by the ease with which we can all travel our lives without questioning. I think that in "Remains of the Day" he examined similar questions where the butler carries out his 'butlering' to the best of his abilities, but in so doing is complicit in his employers abhorrent Nazism, pretty much to the extent of condoning it. I think that Kathy in this novel is in some ways in a similar position being complicit in what can be seen as an abhorrent system. Neither the butler in "Remains of the Day" nor Kathy in this novel question the system - they sometimes question lesser aspects of the system, but they never question the actual system.

The dystopia which Ishiguro presents here is a very ordinary one - in many ways it is not a dystopia at all. It is only when one looks at the bigger picture that this can be seen as a dystopia. Compare this to the case of the "Matrix" world in which the dystopia is obvious and apparent to all. It seems to me that from the point of view of our ancestors of only two or three generations ago, we currently live in a dystopia. We are invisibly tethered to machines throughout the day - and often the night -, observed by "the state" wherever we go, our freedom to travel from country to country tighter now than at any point in history, less secure - both in terms of employment and physical safety - less healthy, less active and less sociable.

Possibly Ishiguro is also trying to answer the question of how can ordinary 'decent' people do terrible things to other human beings as in the case of Nazi Germany.

I think that one message that Ishiguro would like us to take away from this novel is the necessity of questioning 'authority' - not necessarily in order to overturn it, but at least to challenge it.

I do not feel that Ishiguro comes down on one or other sides of the argument - ie: is this a "good" or "bad" thing - and I think that he is right to take this neutral stance. I think that the issues are complex, and that - strong - arguments can be made for both cases.

For what it's worth, my view is that human cloning is 'bad' - this is from a moral viewpoint, but also from a practical one. Morally it is 'bad' because it necessarily 'farms' human beings, and practically because the purpose of the whole thing is to prolong human life, and to escape death for some time. It seems to me that death is a natural part of life, and the resources brought to bear to defer death need to be proportionate.

link.title: [book review] "Never Let Me Go" by Kazuo Ishiguro

entry.title: Preliminary questions prior to discussion of coronavirus response
entry.content:
I am writing this post in August, 2020.  We, in the UK, have been in lockdown since March, 2020, albeit in a slightly relaxed form now, compared to the full strength lockdown that we experienced at first.

I have a view on the lockdown, and on the world’s reaction / response to the pandemic, and I am keen to have rational conversations about this, to test whether my thinking is sensible or not.  However, this seems to be a subject where rational thought goes out of the window, and terror and panic have set in.

As such, I have given some thought to a set of preliminary questions that I would like to put to someone before engaging in debate.

I would rather not have the conversation than fall out with a friend whilst discussing this issue.

So, my preliminary questions are :

  • do you believe that governments should do everything in their power to save a life from coronavirus, or any other cause ?
    • If you answer yes to that, does your feeling extend to government action to prevent road deaths ?
    • How about lung cancer ?
    • How about other forms of cancer ?
    • How about obesity ?
  • do you believe that governments have a responsibility to the economy as well as to life ?
  • do you believe that governments and ministers have to make difficult and nasty decisions that most of us would prefer not to think about ?
  • do you believe that there is a price which is put on lives by the public sector ?
  • do you believe that this is right or wrong ?

Having your answers to these questions will allow me to understand your position, and adjust my conversation accordingly.

link.title: Preliminary questions prior to discussion of coronavirus response

entry.title: Why am I Using a blog, rather than other platforms ?
entry.content:
Why am I making use of a blog, when there are so many other platforms available, through which I could do this ?

I could use Amazon to write book and film reviews; I could use Goodreads; I could use Facebook for photo posts, et cetera.

There are plenty of platforms which I could use, which would not require me to do any extra admin.

So why am I making use of a blog ?

There are two key reasons.

Firstly, it is about data ownership - not data privacy (I personally think that that concern is over blown) - but data ownership. If I write a review on Amazon, who owns that content ? Me, as the author, or Amazon as the platform owner ? If it is Amazon then what control do I have over how that content gets used ? What if Amazon decides to make use of my words in some advertising, without first asking (and receiving) my permission ? I am not sure if this is a likely scenario - I suspect not - but my trust in these platforms is not high.  I know that they all publish detailed terms and conditions which no doubt would give me some indication of which way the wind is blowing, but I do not have the time, the inclination, nor the technical know-how to understand the complicated T&Cs which get published. So, by doing things this way, any reviews that I write, or content that I produce, is very clearly mine, to own and to do with as I like.

The second reason for me adopting this strategy is more subtle, and more difficult to describe.  It boils down to not wanting to shout about what I write about.  If I am on Facebook, and I write something, that something tends to get thrust at all my friends - I do not want that.  If people are interested in what I have to say, that is great, and I want them to be able to see what I have to say, but I do not want it thrust at them.  So, if I write something on the blog, then I can reference it, and if people want to read more / further, then they can.

link.title: Why am I Using a blog, rather than other platforms ?

entry.title: [book review] "Coot Club" by Arthur Ransome
entry.content:
Details of the Book

Title Coot Club
Author Arhtur Ransome
ISBN no ISBN available
Publisher / Imprint Puffin Books

SRM Reading

Took me a week or so, in early 2020 (say February/March).

Headline / Takeaway

An excellent book which I would highly recommend.

Story Synopsis

Link to Wikipedia article on "Coot Club"

Criticism

I enjoyed this book immensely, and have very little in the way of criticism. If I had to pick one thing, which could be termed criticism, it might be the density of the language. By which I mean that a lot of meaning is crammed into very few words. Whilst this is in general a good thing (brevity being the soul of wit, and all that), what it means is that the reader is asked to take on board a lot of information, and to do considerable deciphering, whilst also reading.

Review

I could never get into the Swallows and Amazons book when I was a child - I found it too dense; more recently I have watched the film with my children, and we all enjoyed it.

I still had an old copy of Coot Club, so I decided to tackle it, with a notion that my 9 year old daughter might be persuaded to read it.

What I found - when I’d put my prejudice to one side - was a tremendous story, very well told. I loved the writing style; I loved the imagery; I loved the eventual triumph of good over bad … even though some of the class overtones may strike a bum note in 2020.

I loved the independence that the children have - to explore, and to adventure, without always needing to return to parents for permission. This seems to me to hark back to a bygone age, which we may never be able to re-capture.

entry.title: [images] some pictures what I took !
entry.content: I went for a walk on Sunday afternoon, around a local walk which I like.  It seemed to me that the whole world was bursting into fruit !

entry.title: [book review] "Goodnight Mister Tom" by Michelle Magorian
entry.content:
Details of the Book

Title Goodnight Mister Tom
Author Michelle Magorian
ISBN 978-0-141-35480-4
Publisher / Imprint Puffin Books

SRM Reading

A couple of days,starting 6th August, 2020

Headline / Takeaway

An excellent book which I would highly recommend.

Story Synopsis

Link to Wikipedia article on Goodnight Mister Tom

Criticism

Minimal criticism, beyond the fact that William (Will/Willie) is exceptionally unlucky in his choice of mother - this is so highly unlikely as to be reasonably unbelievable. One is left wondering how the story may have evolved if William's mother had be more "normal" / run-of-the-mill.

Review

This is an excellent story (once you leave aside the sadness/misery porn aspect of it), which is extremely well written. The language is mature and in no way pandering to a child type audience. I found the book to be highly readable, and I tried to find as much time to plough through it as I could.

An aspect which I find interesting to consider, is how social services in 2020 would react to this tale, in comparison with when the story was written (1980) and when it was set (1940). I suspect that 2020 social services would not allow Tom the redemption which was allowed him in earlier generations.

I also think that if this book had been written in 2020, the relationship between Will and Zach would have been cast as a homosexual one, rather than just as boys being great friends, and having fun in each others' company. My feeling is that neither Will nor Zach would see themselves (or think of themselves) as homosexual.

There is lots about this book which makes me very sad, when I consider life in 2020 in the UK.

  • children would not be allowed to roam all day alone in the countryside
  • an older man would not be allowed to adopt a teenage boy
  • children are not allowed the same freedom
  • children are not expected to contribute to housekeeping in the same way
  • very much more emphasis is placed on things/stuff and status than I think was previously the case

I have recently read Arthur Ransom's Coot Club, which contains similar themes of childhood independence and learning by doing and by making mistakes - without parents helicoptering nearby. My feeling is that this change in society is down to fear - fear of the predatory adult; fear of ...

link.title: [book review] "Goodnight Mister Tom" by Michelle Magorian
